last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
So the ultimate question arises.
To watch or not to watch?
The post 2010s produced animes?
Ultimately, you just have to realize that time cannot freeze in an eternal stasis and that one year simply cannot compare to another because the years are different. Everything changes, animation technologies included (not necessarily for the better we must admit). The spirit of time itself is ever-changing. If you want to understand time better, you must watch new animes as well.
If you want to understand yourself better, you must watch new animes as well.
I did say I thought they were too similar to one another but maybe I just haven't found the right flavour to describe their style. All I can do is to keep watching new animes and enjoying them.
If deep down, you are ready to look at this universe and try to appreciate all ot has to offer in the meta-plane of existence of Japanese animation, you accept all animes, old and new as equally rightful, while being aware of the different trends and styles, moods.
This is the only way to perfection as an anime&manga enthusiast.

Answering OP's question, yes, old works deserve remakes.

What's done is done, TG has its merits, but certainly wasted a lot of its potential, so it's only better for it to become a stepping stone in helping author to create superior series. Chaos/kakuja is one example, but this chapter naturally made me reflect on similarities between Noh/Furuta. For me Fruit was saving grace of :re latter half, I still think he was a good character, but far from perfect. He came almost out of nowhere and in large replaced with himself V/Clowns/Eto/Arima, which was too much, at some point he felt like a god with everything going according to his keikaku, even when it was not the case, his dynamic with MC was not that interesting, because Kaneki barely reacted to him and him being super amazing fighter at very last felt like stretch, especially when he already didn't have a chance against Ken. In comparison, Noh already here from chapter 1, he has a few established relationship, he is very powerfull, but it's clear that not everything goes as he imagines, so he feels like important player and not author's avatar, finally, his little banter with Tokio is already much more amusing than every conversation Fruit had with Ken. I hope this continues and CX becomes for Ishida what Real is to Inoe or what HxH is to Togashi, with exception of being finished of course.

threads.com:
There is a chapter that was never compiled in any format since it's original serialization in Big Comic April 10, 1986/April 25, 1986 (ビッグコミック1986年4月10日号・4月25日号). Chapter 237: "Maboroshi no saibai" (幻の栽培, lit. Phantom Cultivation), a.k.a. "Maboroshi (damī) no saibai" (幻の栽培, lit. Cultivation of illusion (dummy)). Chapter 237 was protested by the Iranian embassy due to how the chapter portrayed Iranian leader Ruhollah Khomeini.
>Plot Synopsis:
In the story, members of the Revolutionary Guard, who saw the Iranian people exhausted by the war, directly appeal to Supreme Leader Ruhollah Khomeini to declare the end of the war. However, the actual Khomeini was in a state of senility and could not move, and the Khomeini who appeared in public was a body double arranged by the war continuation faction.

last_replies.com:
Chapter 245. "Suwappu horyo kōkan") (スワップ 捕虜交換, lit. Swap Prisoner Exchange) is not in the SP tankōbon edition, but included in vol. 171 of the sōshūhen edition. The original Big Comic serialization version of the chapter depicted the real "PLO Intelligence Department" as a radical terrorist organization. In reprinted versions of the chapter, the name of the organization to the "Information Department of the Armed Forces for the Liberation of Palestine"
>Plot Synopsis:
Sarah Storm, known as a first-class female agent in the Israeli intelligence service, is captured in Syria by the Palestinian Armed Forces. Khalid, head of the armed alliance intelligence department, thinks of using her as an exchange agent for prisoners of war captured by the Israeli side. Gabriele Kroffe Tiedemann, known as a female terrorist, was chosen as the exchange partner. Meanwhile, Golgo, who has entered Damascus, is arrested by the armed alliance, but receives a request from Khalid to shoot Gabriele. Golgo aimed at the target that appeared at the prisoner exchange site on the bridge over the Jordan River, but the target that was shot through was different from Chief Khalid's designation.
